git-svn-id: https://mary.opendfki.de/repos/trunk@239 953a6561-930b-0410-b2a6-db37d1b2ae63

Introduced a TargetFeatureComputer which can compute a FeatureVector for a given Target.
It uses a new set of feature processors, derived from MaryFeatureProcessor. There are 
ByteValuedFeatureProcessor, ShortValuedFeatureProcessor and ContinuousFeatureProcessor
sub-interfaces; first implementations of ByteValuedFeatureProcessor can be found in 
MaryGenericFeatureProcessors and MaryLanguageFeatureProcessors, which are basically
adapted from GenericFeatureProcessors and LanguageFeatureProcessors, respectively.
Together with a FeatureProcessorManager, they are to replace the previous implementation
as soon as the CART implementation is updated to the new target features.
The new feature processors know their name, their possible values, and can translate
a byte or short value into its string equivalent.
A new output data type TARGETFEATURES has been created; a new module TargetFeatureLister
produces that format. It consists of three sections, separated by empty lines:
a header section, listing byte-valued, short-valued and continuous features along with their
possible values; a string-valued feature vector section, in which all features are listed 
in their string form; and a "binary" or "numerical" section, in which the numerical values
of the feature vectors are listed.
A new config file targetfeatures.config contains the list of feature processors to use.
It is now a question of labour to complete the set of feature processors.

git-svn-id: https://mary.opendfki.de/repos/trunk@350 953a6561-930b-0410-b2a6-db37d1b2ae63

Added the computation of the distance tables to the CARTBuilder.
The acoustic distances between two units are defined as a Mahalanobis
distance between Mel-cepstra, cumulated and averaged along the optimal DTW
path which aligns the Mel-cepstral frames of the two considered units.
  This is not exactly what Alan Black was doing. The pros of our version
are that:
- it closer to what is done in speech recognition;
- it has no "rule of thumb" weights to adjust;
- it is reasonably oblivious to unit duration differences (I don't
  believe in Black's "duration penalty" for acoustic clustering, maybe
  we should discuss this).
The cons is that:
- it is computationally more expensive, but since it is performed
  offline we can probably afford it;
- it does not force an explicit F0 penalty, but: a) I believe that
  the Mel-cepstra contain some pitch information, though this is arguable
  in the case where they come from pitch-synchronous analysis; b) do we really
  want to account for pitch info in the preselection, since we plan to do
  pitch-correction at a further stage; c) if it appears from experience that
  we need a better pitch discrimination in the preselection, we could still
  work out and add our own F0 penalty in a future version.

This commit is untested, because it depends on other parts of the CARTBuilder
which are not yet complete (file names for the distance matrix export etc.).

  of the database import process:
  1) shifting pitchmarks to the closest waveform maximum within +/-2 milliseconds
     of the original mark (this was originally done by the pm_fix script in Festival);
  2) then, shifting to the waveform zero crossing immediately preceding the max,
     within a -2ms neighbourhood (this was NOT done in Festival).
  The second part of Festival's pm_fix script, namely the pitchmark merging/splitting
  intended to ensure that the pitchmarks were at least 0.0025ms and at most 0.02ms apart,
  has been found to have nearly no effect on the arctic database, so has not
  been reproduced in our own code.

- Visual inspection and tuning of the pitchmark max+zero searching
  horizon, using Scilab. +/- 2ms seems to be a good tradeoff to minimize
  the discontinuities and ensure that the discontinuity is going to be
  located in a fast-varying segment of the waveform.

In summary, we should have beautiful pitch periods and much less audible
clics now. To be verified at runtime.
